{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3087242,"name":"","username":"Wing","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/wing/{size}/175245_2.png","created_at":"2022-10-07T00:48:14.696Z","cooked":"

With the limelight tuned and set up in code, I was trying to figure out the optimal mounting angle so that it could see the reflective tape on the upper hub from most places. ideally there are 3 places that we’d like to be able to shoot from, the launch pad, right outside the tarmac, and inside the tarmac. I am however concerned about whether or not the tape on the hub will be visible from all 3 of these locations. Do any teams have suggestions on how to find an optimal mounting angle?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2022-10-07T00:48:14.696Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":752,"reads":465,"readers_count":464,"score":3868.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":415913,"topic_slug":"ideal-limelight-mounting-angle","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":51272,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Waffler"},"post_url":"/t/ideal-limelight-mounting-angle/415913/1","custom_user_title":"Waffler","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true,"can_vote":false},{"id":3087246,"name":"Tom Line","username":"Tom_Line","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tom_line/{size}/236809_2.png","created_at":"2022-10-07T00:59:49.759Z","cooked":"

Put it on your robot. Move the bot close. Adjust so the target is visible at the top of the image. Back the robot to your furthest point. Insure you can see the target. Lock in place. This is one of this situations where making an adjustable mount is better than trying to engineer a perfect angle.

How do you make an adjustable mount? I assume there are probably guides out there already but is it something that can be 3d printed or does it have to be built ourself?

That one looks fine, but as someone in the thread points out, an adjustable camera mount can be a downside. One bump to your robot and you can’t aim for at least the rest of the match, maybe longer if you aren’t able to get it back in the right place. We learned that lesson the hard way at a 2016 offseason event without a practice field…

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2022-10-07T04:38:41.886Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":375,"readers_count":374,"score":115.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":415913,"topic_slug":"ideal-limelight-mounting-angle","display_username":"bobbysq","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":24594,"username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","name":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/slab-mr.thomas/{size}/182153_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":28014,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"he/him"},"post_url":"/t/ideal-limelight-mounting-angle/415913/5","custom_user_title":"he/him","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3087295,"name":"JJ Sessa","username":"jjsessa","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jjsessa/{size}/8845_2.png","created_at":"2022-10-07T05:43:47.097Z","cooked":"

This can be solved using some basic CAD. Draw a ground line, and then a line to represent the vision ring from a side angle, model the vertical FOV of the limelight as a large triangle and play with mounting angles until you can see the ring from all possible shots.

image955×468 76.2 KB

Bonus points for taking this into 3D to check clipping on the hub shoots at various angles.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2022-10-07T05:43:47.097Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":11,"reads":343,"readers_count":342,"score":333.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":415913,"topic_slug":"ideal-limelight-mounting-angle","display_username":"JJ Sessa","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/uploads/default/original/3X/e/d/ed043a421034be5b6a8a9da69dfea1b0ad029a6f.png","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":12}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":27333,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"4414 | Mentor / Coach | Fabworks"},"post_url":"/t/ideal-limelight-mounting-angle/415913/6","custom_user_title":"4414 | Mentor / Coach | Fabworks","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":12}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":12,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3087298,"name":"dirtbikerxz","username":"dirtbikerxz","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/dirtbikerxz/{size}/207955_2.png","created_at":"2022-10-07T06:10:51.086Z","cooked":"

EDIT: lol jj sniped me in the time it took to find our screenshots from 9 months ago

You absolutely want a rigid limelight mount, any unwanted adjustments in angle (even as small as 0.5 degrees) can result in significant issues when it comes to calculating distance and position.

As for what angle to use, you should sketch it out in cad, there is no universal number that “just works”. It heavily depends on your robot (aka the height of the limelight placement). It also heavily depends on your robot’s goals. An angle that might help the robot see the goal from 10-25 feet away won’t help you if your main shooting position is under 10 feet from the goal (and vice versa).

Sketch the vertical FOV from the Limelight in your robot cad and use that to see what the most optimal angle is for your robot to cover the range of the field that you want to cover.

Here’s some screenshots we ended up with while finding our optimal limelight angle.

(Pro tip, you can also sketch horizontal FOV and drag the robot around the field to find where on the field you might be restricted from shoot, how much of a turret angle you might need, if you’re shot profile is going to be clipping the ball return paths off the goal etc etc.)

unknown2757×1160 1.33 MB

unknown (1)2480×1737 872 KB

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2022-10-07T06:15:39.460Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":13,"reads":314,"readers_count":313,"score":177.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":415913,"topic_slug":"ideal-limelight-mounting-angle","display_username":"dirtbikerxz","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/uploads/default/original/3X/1/0/1064c064ded2bc568f25908dc197f0b20dea6a6a.png","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":0},{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/uploads/default/original/3X/d/e/de13a2332bf038ba209987aec204c35f72849e78.png","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":23601,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Rohit - 8044 Drive Coach"},"post_url":"/t/ideal-limelight-mounting-angle/415913/7","custom_user_title":"Rohit - 8044 Drive Coach","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":true,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3087323,"name":"Newton Crosby Jr","username":"NewtonCrosbyJr","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/newtoncrosbyjr/{size}/163897_2.png","created_at":"2022-10-07T11:36:08.882Z","cooked":"

The angle you should do is whatever gives you the best view of the target at whatever distance you are supposed to shoot from. There isn’t a universal best angle, it’s just whatever works best for you. 1895’s limelight was at about 45 degrees, but 1885 did theirs closer to 70 degrees. We also shot from farther away than they did. It’s all relative to how you want your robot to perform.

Also, here’s a pro tip: Don’t tune your limelight until it’s on your robot mounted the way you want. depending on the pitch of the camera, the way it sees ambient light will vary. Also as you mount your camera with a steeper pitch, it’ll reduce how much light is reflected back at the camera and how much it detects ceiling lights, etc. so you’ll need to re-tune your limelight once it is mounted to the bot and at the optimal target range. Tune your camera to work at your best shot, because your best shot should be the most consistent. It seems like a lot of work, but trust me it works. I tuned our limelight to our tarmac line shot and in competition it was about 85%-ish accurate.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2022-10-07T11:36:08.882Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":6,"reads":264,"readers_count":263,"score":82.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":415913,"topic_slug":"ideal-limelight-mounting-angle","display_username":"Newton Crosby Jr","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":51042,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Now availible on DVD and Blu-Ray!"},"post_url":"/t/ideal-limelight-mounting-angle/415913/8","custom_user_title":"Now availible on DVD and Blu-Ray!","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3087326,"name":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/slab-mr.thomas/{size}/182153_2.png","created_at":"2022-10-07T12:01:00.889Z","cooked":"
bobbysq:

adjustable camera mount can be a downside

I found the adjustable mount for the OP but my team didn’t use it. We did the theoretical method and we carefully measured the angle several times at the desired distances then printed a mount to achieve that camera angle.

We also printed more mounts with a couple of angles on each side of the “perfect” angle.

I think using shims may be a fairly good method to get different angles but you have to be sure they can’t move. Maybe some cleaver use of interlocks - grooves, integral pegs and holes, etc. on thin shims would give good results. I think of this adjustable shim method now since despite we making five different angles a sixth version would have been better (the good case for adjustable).

It doesn’t hurt to have a backup mount as my team has had a camera ripped off since for best vision they are mounted high and back on the robot.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2022-10-07T12:01:00.889Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":251,"readers_count":250,"score":70.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":415913,"topic_slug":"ideal-limelight-mounting-angle","display_username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24594,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/ideal-limelight-mounting-angle/415913/9","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3087328,"name":"Patrick","username":"Patrick3357","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/patrick3357/{size}/169915_2.png","created_at":"2022-10-07T12:47:36.525Z","cooked":"

If you aren’t able to get a good angle from CAD print the adjustable mount, find a good angle, then make rigid mount.

If you are a going to try to cad the angles, give yourself wiggle room. You’re talking about a lot of tolerance stack up and if you design right to the edge youre sure to be unhappy with the result.

In the end it’s the programmers that are responsible and they have to go with what they know and it isn’t CAD or a functioning robot. CAD gave us a 3-D printed mount for the tripod.

image292×544 26.1 KB

","post_number":13,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2022-10-07T18:04:49.008Z","reply_count":3,"reply_to_post_number":11,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":178,"readers_count":177,"score":65.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":415913,"topic_slug":"ideal-limelight-mounting-angle","display_username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/uploads/default/original/3X/9/4/94f918302ba05dfa97e4891c87cc38e9c6d3a2a8.png","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":51272,"username":"Wing","name":"","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/wing/{size}/175245_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24594,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/ideal-limelight-mounting-angle/415913/13","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3087402,"name":"JJ Sessa","username":"jjsessa","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jjsessa/{size}/8845_2.png","created_at":"2022-10-07T18:30:34.885Z","cooked":"

A little offtopic, but at the end of the day its the TEAM that is responsible. I would hold the designers at fault if they gave programming a robot that couldn’t see the limelight, but the programming should be giving them all the information, like what camera is being used, in what orientation, and the approximate location of the robot. Fielding a good robot takes a huge balance in different disciplines, and most students should be trying to double dip. Programmers having a touch of cad experience and designers having a touch of controls experience goes a LONG way.

Agreed with @jjsessa , you are definitely right in the sense that as the programmers we have a responsibility to make sure that CAD has all the relevant info but as a team it is our job to support each other, even if it means going into another field in which you don’t usually work in.

jjsessa:

balance in different disciplines, and most students should be trying to double dip

Your post is fine and I was resisting a comment until I saw the little hearts (and comment) piling up. So I have to say that my team must be doing pretty well to win some matches despite having way less resources than many people assume. We are a “medium” resource team and I’ve seen some that have almost nothing.

My programmers didn’t get through the Beginning Java lessons before kickoff let alone learn WPILib. (We’re making adjustments to the curriculum to address that problem and will do better this upcoming season.) So I think we are more a half-dip team than double-dip and it does pretty well.

We changed cameras and camera mounts between our two competitions and did not have a robot to experiment with. CAD was desperately trying to design for improvements to use at the next competition. Build was trying to fix all the broken stuff and implement a climber. The programmers thought using the camera tripod was clever - it was handy and we could make dozens of measurements and realistic tests while being hopeful the robot being worked on by the other groups would be ready for competition.

We aspire to be as great a team as yours - my students love winning. Probably will come up short - they don’t take it too hard.

","post_number":17,"post_type":1,"posts_count":19,"updated_at":"2022-10-07T19:02:28.441Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":14,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":8,"reads":139,"readers_count":138,"score":67.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":415913,"topic_slug":"ideal-limelight-mounting-angle","display_username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24594,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/ideal-limelight-mounting-angle/415913/17","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3092184,"name":"Newton Crosby Jr","username":"NewtonCrosbyJr","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/newtoncrosbyjr/{size}/163897_2.png","created_at":"2022-10-26T17:01:06.885Z","cooked":"

Um, being a programmer, I can tell you it’s not always our job/fault. We had a rigid mount given to us by mechanical with very little say in how it was made. Yes, we had to make it work; but in the end there’s a fairly evenly shared responsibility. We branch CAD under the mechanical umbrella, so naturally our programmers don’t know a whole ton about 3d design. We’ll tell the design team the sort of thing we are looking for and let them fill in the details. If they produce what we ask them and the design is fundamentally flawed, then it’s our fault. But if we were specific in what we wanted, and knew the design would be stable, and the product was poorly produced, it’s not our fault.

The programmers run with whatever physical product mechanical makes up, and mechanical runs with whatever crazy ideas programming dreams up. It’s not one group’s responsibility, it’s the collective’s job to make sure everyone is on the same page.
